messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-29T14:10:44Z
## Message ID: 20161129-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above 10^5 pfu as of 2016-11-29T12:45Z, with the original radiation belt enhancement starting at 2016-11-25T13:35Z (see notifications 20161125-AL-002 and 20161127-AL-001).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-11-24T05:14Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-11-25T13:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above 10^5 pfu. Originally the RBE started on 2016-11-25T13:35Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-11-24T05:14Z.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-25T15:09:14Z
## Message ID: 20161125-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-11-25T03:00Z to 2016-11-25T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-11-24T05:14Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-11-25T03:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 




NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 16, 2016 - November 22, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-23T19:12:12Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-11-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161123-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period starting at 2016-11-16T13:55Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt measured by GOES 13 were associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-11-10 (see notification 20161116-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the enhanced energetic electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-11-19T09:48Z     ~517            C               -65/3                 18                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-11-29T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The active regions on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity.  The geomagnetic activity was slightly elevated on 2016-11-22 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 (speeds only reached values of 526 km/s on 2016-11-26).  The geomagnetic activity may remain slightly elevated due to the arrival of another coronal hole high speed stream in the next couple of days.   

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 09, 2016 - November 15, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-16T21:37:20Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-11-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161116-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest Kp value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-11-11T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This minor increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the combination of an arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2016-11-09T05:28Z of a coronal mass ejection that started on the Sun on 2016-11-05T04:48Z, and a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-11-10.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-11-13T13:10Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt measured by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20161113-AL-001 and 20161113-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the enhanced electron fluxes on the outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-11-09T01:25Z     ~724            C               -49/23                27                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-11-22T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are some active regions presently on the solar surface that may produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections. The geomagnetic activity may slightly increase on the next few days due the arrival of small coronal hole high speed stream.  The outer radiation belt electron fluxes measured by GOES 13 are still above the threshold of 10^5 pfu on 2016-11-16 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notification 20161116-AL-001).  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-13T13:43:27Z
## Message ID: 20161113-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-11-13T13:10Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-11-10T16:38Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-11-13T13:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 02, 2016 - November 08, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-10T01:03:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-11-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161110-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period. CME that started on 2016-11-05T04:48Z as observed by SOHO LASCO C2 was detected to arrive (by DSCOVR) at L1 around 2016-11-09T05:28Z.

Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated at the beginning of the reporting period, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. This elevation was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-10-25.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-11-15T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are some active regions presently on the far side of the Sun that may produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, the CME observed on 2016-11-09T01:25Z (speed around 724 km/s) is expected to impact Mars with a glancing blow around 2016-11-12T08:00Z. The geomagnetic activity is expected to increase around 2016-11-11 due the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 26, 2016 - November 01, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-11-02T21:32:39Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-11-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161102-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  The CME that started on 2016-10-25T19:12Z is believed to have arrived at STEREO A around 2016-10-29T03:00Z.  There is a data gap before this time that makes this arrival time not completely accurate, but the flux rope is observed to arrive later on (see notification 20161026-AL-004). 

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Kp reached moderate levels during the synoptic periods of 2016-10-26T09:00-12:00Z and 2016-10-26T15:00Z-18:00Z.  This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-10-25 (see notification 20161026-AL-003).  The solar wind speed approach values close to 800km/s on 2016-10-26.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu several times for several days during the reporting period starting 2016-10-26T11:00Z.  The significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20161026-AL-001, 20161026-AL-002, 20161028-AL-001, 20161030-AL-001, and 20161031-AL-001, 20161031-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.  


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-11-08T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The active regions present on the solar disk have low magnetic complexity.  We may have a slight increase of geomagnetic activity in the next few days due to a small coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-10-31T09:25Z  in a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that has been ongoing since 2016-10-26T11:00Z (see recent notifications 20161026-AL-001, 20161026-AL-002, 20161028-AL-001, and 20161030-AL-001).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-10-25T09:29Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-10-31T09:25:00-RBE-001.
